timeline.message: apply method config prior to applying interceptor

timeline.bodyText: I don't think we should actually apply the config here. I think we should continue applying the config in ClientCallImpl. That most closely mirrors Envoy and makes it easier to avoiding relying on CallOptions (e.g., outbound max message size should be removed from call options eventually).
timeline.author: ejona86

replies.bodyText: Propagated methodInfo to ClientCallImpl via CallOptions now.
replies.author: dapengzhang0

timeline.bodyText: We need a fast path for when the selector is set, but it is a ManagedChannelServiceConfig.getDefaultConfigSelector(). We should only pay the indirection cost when it is necessary.
timeline.author: ejona86

replies.bodyText: Added a fast path for this below.
replies.author: dapengzhang0

timeline.bodyText: I'm concerned about this double-picking and it assuming we get the same results both times. Could you either migrate the current user of the committedCallback or convert the callback to an interceptor in ConfigSelectingClientCall? It seems that should be really easy. If not, then maybe disable this flow if the CallOptions contain the service config.
timeline.author: ejona86

replies.bodyText: I converted the callback to an interceptor for the moment.  (It seems not working to disable this flow if the CallOptions contain the service config)
replies.author: dapengzhang0

timeline.message: not to apply method config in interceptor

Revert "partially avoud double selection"

This reverts commit 0b7fdceee7a1102f3b93d45628d4b423b3317cb0.
convert the callback to an interceptor

timeline.bodyText: If you want, you can extend NoopClientCall.
timeline.author: ejona86

timeline.bodyText: It's not clear to me why you are storing the CallOptions in the ClientCall instead of just storing the CallOptions in a test field directly.
timeline.author: ejona86

replies.bodyText: I wanted to verify the CallOptions that the underlying call (TestCall) received is as expected, so the CallOption is kind of belonging to the underlying call. I agree it's not so clear by reading the code. Now I use a mock channel instead.
replies.author: dapengzhang0

replies.bodyText: Oh, I preferred how you had it instead of using a Mock. A concrete Channel implementation is far more readable and more useful as tests are added. And argument captures are harder to follow.
replies.author: ejona86

replies.bodyText: Reverted mock channel and added some explanation comments.
replies.author: dapengzhang0

timeline.bodyText: Use TestMethodDescriptors.voidMethod()? I assumed this was done so you could clearly define the method name for service config, but it seems your using the wildcard.
timeline.author: ejona86

timeline.bodyText: I don't see any usefulness of such a test, except it trivially increases the code coverage...
timeline.author: voidzcy

timeline.bodyText: nit: This class looks simple and small (after the interceptor for wrapping the existing committed callback is deleted), so maybe just embedded it in ManagedChannelImpl? But anyway, I am fine with either.
timeline.author: voidzcy
